Kaylee Bravo Mrs. Pinto Early American Literature 26 February 2024 Rough Draft: Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. Somehow, he never let his crown fall. He ate lunch alone in the West Point Military Academy cafeteria, and the other cadets did all possible to make him invisible. He was the only cadet on campus without a roommate. Nor did his four-year cross-country teammates dare speak to him. No one in West Point deemed a black man good enough to even talk to, let alone graduate with excellence among white men. But Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. proved West Point segregated wrong, finishing ranked 35th out of 276 men, white included (Eley). His success continued nationwide, inspiring black men to reach for success and break barriers in a segregated world, one …show more content…

Benjamin O. Davis, Jr.'s outstanding leadership and the skill of the black troops were revealed by the 332nd’s achievements. There is no denying that black men can fight now. Integration is just around the corner. Because of the accomplishments of the 322nd (Tuskegee Airmen), the Deputy Chief of Staff, Lieutenant General Idwall Edwards, conducted a racial segregation study on the U.S. Air Force. He encouraged racial integration to the Chief of Staff with the Tuskegee Airmen and Davis, Jr.’s performance as evidence that black men were as capable as white men in war (Gropman). The Air Force, thanks to Davis, Jr., was the first U.S. military department to begin implementing racial integration. Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. concluded in a 1990 interview his “greatest accomplishment” in his career after retiring: “...[Making] it possible for Coldwell Edwards to integrate the Air Force. That's a simple, straight answer.” When asked what his contribution to making it possible was, Davis, Jr. responded, “...elevating the respect at the United States Air Force headquarters had for black performance in the Army Air Corps and their potential performance in the United States Air Force under conditions of integration.” Davis, Jr. himself revealed that his performance “made it possible” for integration to commence in the Air Force within a series of events (Benjamin O.
